original:
In the past, people knew each other in person. They met at school, in their neighborhoods, or through friends. They saw each other’s faces, heard their voices, and spent time together. Knowing someone meant sharing time and experiences.

Today, things are different. Many relationships begin and stay online. We chat through messages and see pictures, but we don’t know their faces, their voices, or even if they are real. It’s easy to connect, but it’s hard to truly know someone. The way we know people has changed a lot.
simplified:
Before, people met in person and became friends by spending time together. They saw each other’s faces and heard their voices.

Now, many people talk online. They send messages and see pictures, but they don’t always know what the other person looks like or sounds like. Sometimes, they don’t even know if the person is real. It’s easy to meet people, but it’s harder to really know them.

questions.question: What is the main idea of this passage?
choices: We should go outside more to make friends.
Technology makes friendships stronger.
It is harder to truly know someone in the digital age.
Making friends online is better than in person.
questions.hint: The passage explains how relationships have changed from in-person to online, and what is missing now.

questions.question: What does 'truly know someone' mean?
choices: To know someone’s full name and age.
To have deep understanding and connection with someone.
To follow someone online.
To recognize someone’s face.
questions.hint: Think about what it means to really understand a person, not just their name or face.

questions.question: True or False: The author says that modern ways of knowing people are better.
questions.hint: The author doesn’t clearly say it is better or worse.

questions.question: What does “We don’t know their faces, their voices, or even if they are real.” mean?
choices: We always talk to strangers online.
We never show our faces when talking online.
We often don’t know the physical features or real identity of people online.
Everyone online uses fake names and voices.
questions.hint: The sentence talks about what is missing in online communication.

questions.question: How has the way we know people changed?
choices: We talk more face to face now.
People write letters to each other.
We now meet and talk more online.
We make fewer friends today.
questions.hint: Think about what the passage says about modern relationships.

original:
Parenting is full of questions and doubts. Many people read books or watch videos about how to raise children. These resources often share ideas on making kids smart or successful. But what works for one child might not work for another. Every child is different, and every parent faces different problems. There is no perfect guide.

Most of parenting is learned through daily life. Parents comfort crying babies, clean up messes, and make quick decisions. They do their best, but often feel unsure. Being a parent doesn’t come with one clear answer. It’s a journey full of learning and change.
simplified:
Parents often don’t know the best way to raise children. Books and videos give advice, but each child is different. What works for one may not work for another.

Parents learn by doing. They care for crying babies and make many choices every day. There is no perfect way. Parents do their best and learn over time.

questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?
choices: Parents should read more books about parenting.
There is no single correct way to raise children.
Only experts know how to raise children.
All parents must follow the same rules.
questions.hint: The passage talks about how each child and situation is different.

questions.question: What does 'There is no perfect guide' mean?
choices: There are no books on parenting.
No one wants to be a parent.
Every situation needs a different answer.
Children do not like rules.
questions.hint: Think about what 'perfect guide' means in the context of parenting advice.

questions.question: True or False: All parenting books work for every child.
questions.hint: The passage says children are different.

questions.question: What does 'Being a parent doesn’t come with one clear answer' mean?
choices: Parents must study a lot.
There are many ways to be a good parent.
Only teachers can be good parents.
There is one best way to raise kids.
questions.hint: Think about the idea of uncertainty in parenting.

questions.question: How do parents mostly learn how to raise children?
choices: By watching TV.
By reading books.
By practicing daily life with their child.
By asking other parents.
questions.hint: The passage talks about learning through experience.
